Chapter on Describing the Buddha, Chapter 21 of the Dharmapada Sutra. Describing the Buddha means to describe the Buddha's spiritual virtues, which are of great benefit and liberation, and to clarify his being the model for the world.
One's own victory does not accept evil, victorious over all in the world,
With profound wisdom, vast and boundless, dispelling ignorance and causing entry into the Way.
Resolving doubts without obstruction, with the end of craving, accumulating nothing,
The Buddha's mind is profoundly limitless, causing those who have not yet practiced to practice.
Courageous and strong, establishing single-mindedness, leaving the household life, day and night extinguishing,
Cutting off the roots, with no desirous thoughts, studying right mindfulness, clear and bright.
Seeing the truth, pure and unstained, already crossing over the abyss of the five destinies,
The Buddha appears, illuminating the world, removing the worries and sufferings of the masses.
It is difficult to be born in the human realm, and difficult to obtain birth and longevity;
It is difficult for the world to have a Buddha, and it is difficult to hear the Buddha's teachings.
Since I have no one to rely on, and I am also alone without companions,
I have accumulated one practice and attained Buddhahood, naturally penetrating the path of sagehood.
The boatman can cross the water, and diligence is the bridge.
People are bound by their clan, and the one who crosses is the valiant hero.
Destroying evil and crossing over becomes a Buddha, stopping on the ground becomes a Brahmin,
Eliminating hunger becomes studying the Dharma, cutting off the seeds becomes a disciple.
Contemplating practice, patience is supreme, the Buddha says nirvana is the best.
Abandoning sin and becoming a monk, do not harm others.
Do not harm or trouble, like keeping all precepts,
Eating little and abandoning greed for the body, practicing in secluded places.
The mind is true and has skillful means, this is able to uphold the Buddha's teachings.
Do not do any evil, practice all that is good, purify one's own mind,
These are the teachings of the Buddha.
The Buddha is the most venerable, having severed defilements and abandoned desire, the foremost among the ÅšÄkyas, leading his followers according to his will.
How delightful! The rewards of blessings, all wishes fulfilled, swiftly attaining the supreme peace, and attaining nirvÄá¹‡a on one's own.
Some take refuge in mountains, rivers, tree spirits, and gods, setting up shrines and images,
making offerings and seeking blessings.
Taking refuge in this way is not auspicious, not supreme, and they are unable to come and deliver us from our many sufferings.
If one takes refuge in the Buddha, the Dharma, and the noble Sangha, with the four noble truths and moral conduct, one will surely see right wisdom.
The extreme suffering of birth and death can be liberated through the truths, and the eightfold path of the world
removes all suffering.
Taking refuge in the Three Jewels is the most auspicious, the most supreme, and only this can deliver from all suffering.
The gentleman is upright, his will is not stingy towards the Way, how beneficial!
Such a person, who takes refuge in the Buddha,
The wise are difficult to encounter, and are not to be found everywhere, where they are born,
Their relatives are blessed with joy.
The arising of the Buddhas is wonderful, the preaching of the sutras is wonderful, the harmony of the assembly is wonderful, harmony is always peaceful.

The Chapter on Peace and Tranquility, the Chapter on Peace and Tranquility, the Sutra of the Collection of the Wise and the Worthies, Chapter 20, 34 chapters. The Chapter on Peace and Tranquility discusses the differences in peace and danger, removing evil and immediately becoming good, being joyful without falling into it.
My birth is already peaceful, I do not resent those who hate me, the multitude have resentment,
I act without resentment;ğŸ”½My birth is already peaceful, I am not sick with illness, the multitude have illness, I act without illness;
My birth is already peaceful, I am not sorrowful with worry, the multitude have worry, I act without worry.
My birth is already peaceful, pure, and free from afflictions, taking joy as food,
like the Ä€bhÄsvara gods.
My birth is already peaceful, tranquil, and free from affairs. Even if the fire of the Ká¹›ta Yuga could burn, how could it burn me?
Victory gives rise to resentment, and defeat leads to self-contempt. Abandoning the mind of victory and defeat, being free from contention is peaceful.
There is no heat like passion, no poison like anger, no suffering like the body,
and no joy like cessation.
Without joy, small joy, small eloquence, and small wisdom, observing and seeking the great, one attains great peace.
I am the World-Honored One, eternally free from worry, rightly crossing the three existences, alone subduing the many demons.
Seeing the sages is joyful, being able to rely on them is joyful, being able to leave the foolish,
being good and alone is joyful, guarding the right path is joyful, skillfully expounding the Dharma is joyful,
being without contention with the world;
The precepts are always delightful, relying on the virtuous is delightful, like a gathering of relatives, approaching the wise and intelligent, with much learning and lofty understanding.
Life is short, and those who abandon the world are many, one should learn to take the essentials,
and attain peace until old age.
Those who wish to attain immortality, abandon desires and extinguish the truths of delight,
if they wish to cross over the suffering of birth and death, they should partake of the taste of immortality.
Chapter on Delight, Chapter 24 of the Fa Jue Jing, with 12 sections. The chapter on delight means that when a person is restrained and delights in not being greedy, then there will be no worries.
Going against the Way is self-accord, following the Way is self-contradiction,

Those who delight in performing good deeds go from here to the other shore, and themselves enjoy the blessings,
like a loved one coming with joy.
Arise and follow the teachings, restrain the unwholesome, be close to the path and see what is loved, and stay away from what is not the path.
Those who are close and those who are not, their abodes are different. Being close to the path, one ascends to heaven; being not close, one falls into hell.

Chapter 25: The Chapter on Anger, also known as the Chapter on the Dharma Phrases of the Twenty-Six Verses on Anger. Those who are angry and harmful, but are magnanimous, kind, and gentle, are blessed by the heavens and loved by people.
Those who are angry do not see the Dharma, those who are angry do not know the Way.
Those who can remove anger, their blessings and joy always follow their bodies;
Those who are greedy and lustful do not see the Dharma, and those with foolish minds are the same.
Those who remove lust and eliminate foolishness, their blessings are the most honored.
Anger can be controlled, like stopping a runaway chariot, this is a good charioteer,
Abandoning darkness and entering into light.
Forbearance is superior to anger, goodness is superior to evil, the superior one is able to give, sincerity is superior to deception.
Not deceiving, not angry, and not seeking too much - these three things, upon death, ascend to the heavens.
Always controlling one's body, with a compassionate mind, not killing, this leads to rebirth in the heavens,
Arriving there, without worries.
The mind always alert, aspiring to diligently study, with the defilements exhausted and the mind liberated, one can attain nirvana.
From ancient times to the present, much speaking is criticized, and also slow forbearance is criticized,
And also moderation is criticized - in the world, there is nothing that is not criticized. Desires are not noble,
Unable to control the middle.
One criticism, one praise, but for profit and fame, what the wise praise, only calling it virtuous.
The wise person guards the precepts, without being criticized or slandered, like an arhat who is pure, not falsely accused.
All people praise and the Brahma and Åšakra praise, always carefully guarding the body,
protecting against anger;
eliminating evil conduct of the body, advancing to cultivate virtuous conduct, always carefully guarding speech, protecting against anger;
eliminating evil words of the mouth, reciting and practicing the Dharma, always carefully guarding the mind, protecting against anger.
Eliminating evil thoughts of the mind, contemplating and recollecting the Way, restraining the body and carefully guarding speech,
guarding and controlling the mind.
Abandoning anger and practicing the Way, patience is the strongest;
abandoning anger and avoiding conceit, avoiding all gatherings of desire.
Not attached to name and form, unconditioned and extinguishing suffering, arising and resolving anger, lust arises and self-restraint.
Abandoning ignorance and strength, all attain peace, anger cut off and sleeping peacefully,
Anger destroys lust and worry.
Anger is the root of poison. A gentle brahmin says good words are praised. Cutting off is free from trouble.
Associating with like-minded people, carefully doing evil together, later separating and hating each other, the fire burns and torments oneself.
Not knowing shame or disgrace, lacking precepts and having anger, being dragged by anger,
not being disgusted with busyness.ğŸ”½Having strength is close to soldiers, having no strength is close to softness. Forbearance is supreme. One should always endure weakness;
The multitude looks down on it. The strong endure. Forbearance is supreme. One should always endure weakness.
For myself and others, there are three great fears. Knowing others do this,
One should extinguish it within oneself;
Both sides practice the principle. I teach for others. Knowing others do this, one should extinguish it within oneself.
The wise conquer the foolish through suffering, coarse words, and evil speech. Those who always wish to conquer should remain silent when speaking.
For those who do evil, anger begets angry retribution. But if one does not retaliate with anger,
one conquers the defeated in battle.

Chapter on Dust and Dirt, Chapter 26 of the Fa Jue Jing, with 19 sections. The chapter on dust and dirt discusses distinguishing between purity and turbidity. Those who study should be pure and clean, without defiling conduct.
Born without good conduct, after death one falls into evil paths, dwelling in the uninterrupted hell,
arriving at a place without resources.
One should seek wisdom to illuminate the mind and concentration, remove defilements and avoid pollution, and thus escape the suffering of form.
The wise gradually advance step by step, washing away the defilements of the mind, like a craftsman refining gold;
evil arising in the mind will destroy one's body, like rust on iron,
eating away at one's own body.
Not reciting is verbal defilement, not being diligent is household defilement,
Not being adorned is physical defilement, being heedless is karmic defilement,
Stinginess is the defilement of generosity, unwholesomeness is the defilement of conduct,
In this life and the next, unwholesome dharmas are always defilements.
Among defilements, none is greater than delusion. One should study to abandon evil,
Bhiká¹£us are without defilements.
If one shamelessly lives like a bird with a long beak, enduring humiliation with a strong face, it is called a defiled life;
Though uprightness and shame are difficult, one should take the righteous and pure, avoiding humiliation without falsehood, which is called a pure life.
Foolish people delight in killing, their words lack sincerity, they take what is not given,
They delight in violating others' wives, indulging in breaking precepts, and are deluded by alcohol,
Such people, life after life, dig their own roots.
If a person is aware of this, they should not think of evil. The foolish approach non-dharma, and will be burned and submerged for a long time.
If one has faith in giving, and wishes to spread their fame, gathering people in vain adornment,
It is not entering pure concentration.
Cutting off all desires, severing the root of the mind, guarding the one throughout day and night, one will surely enter concentrated intention.
Attachment to defilement is dust, arising from defiled dust-leaks. Not being defiled, not acting, pure and free from foolishness.
Seeing oneself being invaded, always internally reflecting, practicing with leaks deceiving oneself,
With the exhaustion of leaks, there is no defilement.
There is no heat greater than lust, no swiftness greater than anger,
No subtlety in the net greater than delusion, the flowing of love is swifter than a river.
Space has no tracks, Å›ramaá¹‡as have no external thoughts,
All people delight in evil, only the Buddha is pure and undefiled;
Space has no tracks, Å›ramaá¹‡as have no external thoughts,
The world is all impermanent, the Buddha has no self or possessions.

The Chapter on Upholding, Chapter 27 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with seventeen sections. Those who uphold the Dharma understand the meaning of the Way. The Dharma values virtuous conduct and does not indulge in greed.
Those who delight in the Way do not compete for gain, whether there is gain or no gain,
Without desire, they are unconfused, always compassionate towards those who delight in learning, and practice with a correct mind,
Embracing the precious wisdom in their hearts, this is called the Way.
So-called wisdom does not necessarily mean eloquent speech;
Without fear or dread, guarding goodness is wisdom.
Those who uphold the Dharma do not speak much;
Although they may have heard little, if they rely on the Dharma in their bodies, guarding the Way without forgetting, they can be called upholders of the Dharma.
As for the old, it is not necessarily one who is aged, with a mature body and white hair,
but rather a fool.
It means to embrace the truth, to be gentle and kind, to be bright, far-reaching, and pure, and this is considered an elder.
As for the handsome, it is not necessarily one who is as beautiful as a flower, stingy, jealous, and hypocritical, with words and actions contradicting each other;
it means to be able to abandon evil, with its roots already severed, to be wise and without anger,
and this is considered handsome.
As for the Å›ramaá¹‡a, it is not necessarily one who shaves their hair, speaks falsely, greedily takes, and has desires like an ordinary person;
it means to be able to stop evil, to be magnanimous and propagate the Way, to rest the mind and extinguish thoughts, and this is considered a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
As for the bhiká¹£u, it is not necessarily one who begs for food at the wrong time, engages in sexual misconduct,
and merely claims the name;
It means abandoning evil and merit, purely cultivating the brahma conduct, and wisdom can destroy evil, this is a bhiká¹£u.
It is called benevolence and clarity, not speaking without the mouth, the mind is not pure, only conforming externally;
It means the mind is without action, internal practice is pure and empty, this and that are extinguished,
This is called benevolence and clarity.
It is said to have the Way, not to save a single thing;
Universally delivering the world, non-harming is the Way.
The precepts are not said to be many, I practice with sincerity.
Those who attain concentration, must close and reduce, the mind understands and seeks peace.
Do not follow ordinary people, causing bonds to be not yet exhausted, unable to attain liberation.

Chapter on Practicing the Way, Chapter on Practicing the Way, Dharma Phrases Sutra, Chapter 28, 28 Chapters, The Chapter on Practicing the Way, the purport is to expound the great essentials of the path of liberation, this is the ultimate subtlety.
The eightfold right path is the supreme way, the four truths are the Dharma traces.
The honored one who abstains from sexual activity, giving lamps will surely obtain eyes.
This path is without fear, seeing purity one crosses over the world.
This can destroy the army of Mara, practicing with strength extinguishes evil suffering.
I have already opened the right path, manifesting great and wondrous illumination.
Having heard, one should practice oneself, practicing one then understands the bonds of evil.
Birth and death are impermanent and suffering, being able to contemplate and see is wisdom.
Desiring to leave all suffering, practicing the way eliminates all;
Birth and death are impermanent and empty, being able to contemplate and see is wisdom.
Desiring to leave all suffering, one should just diligently practice the way.
When arising, one should immediately arise, do not be like a fool covering a deep abyss.
Together with those who fall without looking at a heap, considering giving up and not progressing on the path.
Contemplation should be correct when contemplated, contemplation that is not appropriate is wrong.
Wisdom that does not give rise to wrong views, contemplating the right path, is accomplished.
Be cautious in speech, guard the mind, and do not engage in unwholesome bodily actions.
The Buddha said that eliminating these three actions leads to attaining the Way.
Cutting down a tree without cutting the root, it will grow again.
Only by removing the root is there no tree; the bhiká¹£u attains nirvÄá¹‡a.
Unable to cut down the tree, relatives cling to each other, greedy thoughts bind themselves,
like a calf yearning for milk;
Only by cutting off the root of the mind, with no end to birth and death, is one close to the Way and quickly attains nirvÄá¹‡a.
Greed leads to aging, anger leads to illness, and delusion leads to death. Eliminating these three leads to attaining the Way.
Releasing the past and understanding the future, liberating from the present and crossing over to the other shore, all thoughts cease,
and there is no more aging or death.
People take care of their wives and children, not observing the impermanent nature of illness, death and life suddenly arrive, like a rushing torrent.
Even father and son cannot save each other, let alone other relatives.
When life ends, relying on relatives is like a blind person guarding a lamp.
Wisdom and understanding are the mind, which can cultivate the sutras and precepts, diligently practicing to transcend the world,
eliminating all suffering.
Far away from all afflictions, like wind dispelling clouds, having extinguished thoughts, this is called knowledge and vision.
Wisdom is the guide of the world, peacefully enjoying non-action, knowing to accept the correct teachings, and ending birth and death.
Knowing the emptiness of all practices, this is called the wisdom vision, abandoning and despising the suffering of the world,
following this path to eliminate it;
Knowing the suffering of all practices, this is called the wisdom vision, abandoning and despising the suffering of the world, following this path to eliminate it;
The various practices are not the body, this is the view of wisdom, abandoning and disliking worldly suffering, from this the path is removed.
I speak the Dharma to you, the arrow of love shoots, you should encourage yourself,
and accept the words of the TathÄgata.
I am completely extinguished, going and coming in birth and death are ended,
not understood by a single thought, what is expounded is the eye of the path.
The swift current pours into the ocean, the flowing water sways and quickly fills,
therefore it is said for the wise, one can head towards and imbibe the sweet dew.
The Dharma wheel that was not heard before, turning for the sake of the suffering multitude,
thus those who serve and respect it, pay homage to it and transcend the three existences.
The three thoughts are good to be thought of, the three are also difficult to be not good,
from thought there is action, extinguishing it is right elimination.
The three concentrations are to turn the thoughts, abandoning reliance and practicing immeasurably,
Attaining the three and three caves, removing, understanding the knots, one should contemplate.
Knowing to restrain evil through precepts, contemplating the joy of wisdom and mindfulness,
Already knowing the success and failure of the world, the mind at rest, all understanding.

The chapter on Extensive Development, the Sutra of the Dharma Verses, chapter 29, with 14 sections. The chapter on Extensive Development speaks of the accumulation of good and evil, from small to great, verifying the corresponding verses.
Although giving peace is small, its reward is great;
Wisdom comes from small giving, receiving and seeing auspicious blessings.
Toiling for others, while hoping for help, misfortune returns to oneself, bringing about widespread resentment.
Having done many things, non-things are also created, indulging in music and negligence, evil habits increase day by day.
Only practicing diligently, abandoning this and that, cultivating the body and awakening oneself,
This is the correct practice.
Having already understood wisdom and also studied much, gradually progressing to vastness, like oil and butter poured into water;
Lacking wisdom and not enjoying studying, condensed and narrow, like curds and butter poured into water.
Approaching the Way is called manifest, like a snow-capped mountain; the distant Way is obscure,
like an arrow shot in the night.
Being a Buddha's disciple, always awakening oneself, day and night contemplating the Buddha, only the Dharma thinking of the assembly;
Being a Buddha's disciple, one should awaken oneself, at dusk thinking of meditation, happily contemplating single-mindedness.
People should have mindful thoughts, knowing to eat less each time,
then pain and desire will be diminished, and one will preserve life by digesting in moderation.
Studying is difficult, abandoning sin is difficult, living at home is also difficult,
Meeting and abiding together in benefiting is difficult, there is no difficulty more difficult than having.
It is difficult for bhiká¹£us to beg for alms, how can one not encourage oneself?
Through diligence, one attains naturally, later having no desires for others.
If there is faith, then precepts are established, following precepts one attains many treasures,
and also from there one finds harmony, wherever one goes one is seen and offered worship.
Sitting once, lying down once, in one practice without indulgence,
guarding one's body with correctness, the mind delights in dwelling among trees.
The Chapter on Hells, Chapter 30 of the Dharmapada, with 16 sections. The Chapter on Hells discusses the affairs of the hells. Doing evil and receiving evil, sins pull one in and do not let go.
Lying is close to hell, doing it and saying one did not do it,
afterwards receiving both sins, this action pulls one there by oneself.
The Dharma robes are on one's body, doing evil and not restraining oneself,
if one is submerged in evil conduct, in the end one will fall into hell.
How can one who has no precepts and receives offerings not harm oneself?
After death, one will eat burning iron pellets, as hot as burning charcoal.
There are four things in indulgence:
Liking to violate others' wives, lying in danger and not benefiting, slandering the Three [Jewels], and indulging in lust.
Not benefiting, falling into evil, fearing evil, fearing few pleasures,
The king's law adds heavy punishment, and after death one enters hell.
It is like pulling cogon grass, if held loosely it will injure the hand,
If one studies the precepts but does not restrain oneself, one will be recorded in prison and harm oneself.
If a person's behavior is lazy and indulgent, and one cannot eliminate various troubles,
The practice of purity will be flawed, and one will never receive great blessings.
Always practice what should be practiced, and firmly uphold it yourself,
Stay far away from non-Buddhists, do not practice and become defiled.
Doing what should not be done, and then causing distress,ğŸ”½...
Always following goodness and auspiciousness, wherever one goes, there is no regret or stinginess.
As for those who engage in various evil deeds, whether intending to do so or having already done so,
This suffering is difficult to understand, and the sin is close, hard to avoid.
Falsely accusing and seeking defeat, engaging in improper conduct, maliciously slandering good people,
And unjustly punishing scholars.
Sin binds such a person, who throws themselves into a pit, like a border city, with the inside and outside firmly guarded.
Guarding one's own mind, non-dharma does not arise. Deficient conduct leads to worry and causes one to fall into hell.
What should be ashamed is not ashamed, and what should not be ashamed is on the contrary ashamed. Born with wrong views,

After death, one falls into hell;ğŸ”½What should be feared is not feared, and what should not be feared is on the contrary feared. Believing in and following wrong views, after death, one falls into hell;
What should be avoided is not avoided, and what should be approached is not pursued. Indulging in wrong views, after death, one falls into hell;
If it can be approached, then approach it; if it can be avoided, then avoid it. Always guard the correct view,
and when death comes, one will fall into a good realm.

The Elephant Simile Chapter, Chapter 31 of the Dharma Verses Sutra, with eighteen sections. The Elephant Simile Chapter teaches people to rectify their bodies, do good, receive good blessings, and have pleasant rewards.
I am like an elephant in battle, not afraid of being hit by arrows, always using sincerity and trust,
to save those who do not keep precepts.
Just as a well-trained elephant can be ridden by the king, a well-disciplined person can receive sincerity and trust.ğŸ”½Even if always well-trained, like a newly trained horse,
a well-trained elephant is not as good as self-discipline.ğŸ”½That which cannot reach where people cannot go,
only the self-disciplined one
can reach the place of discipline.ğŸ”½Like the elephant named Wealth-Keeper, fierce and difficult to restrain,
bound and not given food, yet still a violent and unruly elephant.
Those who are mired in evil deeds, always bound by greed,
The elephant does not know satiety, thus it enters the womb repeatedly.
The original intention is for pure practice, and for the peace of constant practice,
Completely abandoning and subduing the bonds, like a hook controlling a well-trained elephant.
Delighting in the path, not being negligent, able to always protect one's mind,
This is called extracting the suffering of the body, like an elephant emerging from a pit.
If one obtains a wise and capable companion, together practicing good and courageous deeds,
Able to subdue all that is heard, arriving without losing the intention;
If one does not obtain a wise and capable companion, together practicing evil and courageous deeds,
Destroying the villages and towns extensively, it is better to be alone and not do evil.
It is better to be alone and do good, not associating with fools,
Alone and not doing evil, like an elephant startled and protecting itself.
Being born with benefit and ease, a soft and harmonious companion is comfortable,
When life ends, it is peaceful due to merit, and peace comes from not committing any evil.
Having a mother is happiness for a family, and having a father is also happiness.
Having Å›ramaá¹‡as in the world is happiness, and having the Way in the world is happiness.
Upholding the precepts is peaceful until old age, and having faith in the true and practicing what is right is good.
Wisdom is the most peaceful for the body, and not committing evil is the most peaceful.
Like a well-trained horse that goes wherever one wishes, faith, precepts, diligence,
and concentration are essential.
With clear practice established, enduring and harmonious concentration, this ends all suffering and goes wherever one wishes.
From here one goes to certainty, like a well-trained horse. Ending anger and eliminating defilements, this is the heavenly bliss one receives.
Not indulging oneself, one becomes more awakened from this. A weak horse is compared to a good one,
and abandoning evil is being virtuous.
Chapter 32: On Desire, Dharma Phrases Sutra, Chapter 32, 32 sections. The chapter on desire means despising lust and affection. Worldly people, because of this, give rise to many disasters.
The mind is placed in lustful practices, and desires and love increase branches and twigs.
Distributing and growing luxuriantly, leaping and greedy for fruits like a monkey.
Taking it as love and enduring suffering, greed and desire are attached to the world.
Sorrows and worries grow day and night, spreading like vines.
People are confused by affection and love, unable to abandon emotional desires.
Thus, worries and love are many, filling the pond like a stream.
The reasons for sorrow and grief, worldly suffering is not one.
But it is only because of love that there is existence, apart from love there is no worry.
If one's mind is at ease and abandons worry, without love, how can there be a world?
Not worrying, not being tainted and seeking, not loving, how can one attain peace?
There is worry at the time of death, causing many relatives and loved ones,
To tread the long road of worry, loving suffering always falling into danger.
For those who practice the Way, do not unite with desire, first exterminate the root of love,
Do not plant any roots, do not cut reeds, allowing the mind to grow again.
Just as a tree with deep roots, although cut it still grows back,
If loving thoughts are not completely removed, one will certainly return to suffering.
Like a monkey who escapes from a tree, but is freed and returns to the tree,
So are the masses, leaving prison and returning to prison.
Greedy thoughts are always flowing, habits and arrogance together,
Thoughts of lust and desire, covering oneself and seeing nothing.
All thoughts flow everywhere, loving bonds like vines and brambles,
Only wisdom can discern and see, able to cut off the root of the mind.
Husband and wife are moistened by love, and thoughts grow like vines,
The depths of desire are bottomless, and old age and death are thereby increased.
The branches of birth are endless, only using food to satisfy desire,
